msgSnippet: I m with Mike on this one. Test code is supposed to be small and very straight-forward, otherwise it ends up needing testing itself! So combine small/short

Subject: RE: [junit] Javadocing test case and other test classes?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=88072055

I'm with Mike on this one.

Test code is supposed to be small and very stra=
ight-forward, otherwise it ends up needing testing itself! So combine small=
/short code methods with very meaningful method names and I think that shou=
ld be enough for all but the most complex tests.

If you have a complex tes=
t, then by all means write a standard comment in the code explaining what a=
nd why. But unless I had a customer who had contracted to receive documente=
d unit tests, then I'd skip the JavaDoc as well.

As J.B. likes to say, the=
y're programmer tests, written by programmers for themselves, so given that=
 unit tests are not typically a deliverable, why document them over and abo=
ve what YOU need to be able to understand them.

Just my 1/50th of a U.S. F=
ederal Reserve Note.

Simon

>From: Kevin Kline=

>
>
>Does that mean that you don't include a coment f=
or the test method? 
>FWIW again, I always include javadoc of the methods i=
n my test
>classes, with a description of what the setUp is setting up, or =
what
>the test method is intended to do.
>
>From that point of view, if you=
're delivering the unit tests, and
>expecting them to do anything with it, =
I'd think you'd want to deliver
>the javadoc as well.
>
>-Kevin
>
>

show the class and method names.  You get that same information when

 run the tests.
